name: Lindelöf hypothesis
rephrased: The Lindelöf hypothesis states that the Riemann zeta function, when evaluated on the critical line (where the real part is 1/2), does not grow too quickly as the imaginary part becomes large. Specifically, its size is bounded by a very slow-growing function of the imaginary part.
implication_form: If the Riemann hypothesis is true, then the Lindelöf hypothesis holds.
explained: The Lindelöf hypothesis is a conjecture concerning the growth of the Riemann zeta function ζ(s) on the critical line, where s = 1/2 + it for real t. It states that for any ε > 0, ζ(1/2 + it) does not grow faster than any positive power of |t| as |t| approaches infinity. More formally, it asserts that lim sup_{|t| → ∞} |ζ(1/2 + it)| / |t|^ε = 1. This means that ζ(1/2 + it) is bounded by a constant times |t|^ε for large |t| and any ε > 0.
